Award.AwardTitle: TUES Type 1: A Sustainability Toolbox for Engineers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This TUES Type 1 project is creating a sustainability toolbox and evaluating a combination of traditional and non-traditional teaching pedagogy applied toward training engineers to be change agents capable of ethically and competently converting care into action for a sustainable world. This project evaluates six teaching strategies (interventions) within an ethics of care approach, four at the sophomore level and two at the senior design level. Key components of increasingly non-traditional approaches to teaching sustainability are: (a) the use of dramatized video to emotionally engage and motivate students in problems of sustainability and (b) the use of online skill building tutorials that explicitly prepare the student to solve "wicked" problems that require higher order cognitive skills to formulate and address. The PACT (Promoting, Accounting, Compensating, and Targeting) approach to designing for sustainability is incorporated, so that students can transform their awareness of and responsibility for sustainability into meaningful action, regardless of the type and purpose of design.

The strategies are oriented around consumer electronics, whose life cycle remains an unsustainable, widely proliferating beast of consumption that shows little sign of slowing in the modern world. Unlike many other facets of the engineering curriculum, evaluating critical thinking or problem solving in the area of sustainability is not enough to assess whether a student is trained well. Instead, the student must use these high-level thinking skills in often unstructured series of complex, interwoven problems that are situated in an effective transformation of care into action. Through a carefully designed series of interventions and assessments oriented around teaching sustainability, this project offers insight into what teaching approaches work best for improving student learning about the "wicked" problems typically found at the intersection of technology and sustainability.

The importance of training engineers not simply to be aware but also to be appropriately responsible and sufficiently competent in caring about (and acting on) sustainability issues has broad societal impacts. The developed interventions and strategies have the potential to be adopted/adapted by other engineering fields. By addressing an important social issue such as sustainability and showing the important role of engineers in solving this problem, some students might be more attracted to engineering as a career and be more likely to remain in the field. In addition, interventions that connect sustainability to technology can be used to enhance the image of engineering as a career that directly benefits society, thereby enabling engineering to appeal more broadly to students at all stages in K-16 pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to figure out what engineering students think sustainability is and how to best teach these students to understand, support, and contribute to a more sustainable future.   Engineers are in a powerful position to design, develop, and promote products that allow this generation to thrive without compromising the ability of future generations to survive and thrive as well.   Yet, profit-driven product development cycles often prevent engineers from doing as much as they could to protect the environment and to promote social and economic equality around the world.  As sustainable development and practice becomes more critical to the future success and possibly even the existence of civilization, the burden is on educators to teach students early on in higher education what sustainability is and how to make better choices for sustainable practice in their chosen profession.   Making these teaching decisions involves far more than figuring out what to teach and how to teach it, but also must consider student resistance, preconceptions, and misconceptions that can dilute or diminish even the most well thought out curriculum.  This project has focused on developing educational materials that are contemporary and relevant to electrical engineering but also closely linked to critical sustainability issues. These materials have been tested out in seven different classes over the course of the project with students ranging from freshman to senior levels and revised according to find the best compromise between linking to the student experience in a meaningful and believable way and remaining true to the social, economic, and environmental pillars of sustainable development at a global level. 

Among engineering students, we found that the younger the student, the more he or she was likely to believe that understanding the formal definition of sustainability was superfluous to an engineering education and that studying challenges to sustainable technology are better suited to a standalone course than an integrated part of the engineering education from start to finish.  Unfortunately, these beliefs are at odds with developing the skills, the ethics, and the focus on sustainable practice necessary to be an agent of change in an engineering career.  To accommodate students at their point of departure while still advocating for sustainability to be a central part of an electrical engineering education, we developed educational materials that vary with educational level.  For the freshman/sophomore level, we focus on specific environmental impacts of electronics technology (electronic waste, electric vehicles, vampire power consumption) that can be analyzed using the basic mathematical and circuits tools that engineers have in their pockets early in their college education. For the senior level, we focus on the more complex world of engineering design and the many social, environmental, and economic considerations that must be taken into an account as a design evolves from an idea to an eventual product.  

Complementing the intellectual merit of our applied research and resulting educational materials, we also developed tools for researchers to measure a student’s global citizenship values, perspectives on sustainability, and anticipated contributions to a more sustainable world over the course of their careers and their lives as a consumer.   Our project resulted in multiple conference publications, a workshop tutorial, and a submitted journal publication.  However, to ensure broader impact outside the academic community., we have extended dissemination well beyond conventional academic venues to dedicated web pages, YouTube, Slideshare, our annual 5000-participant open house at the University of Washington, and other venues.   Through our surveys, interviews, focus groups, classroom observations, and analysis of engineering curricula around the United States, we found that engineering instruction emphasizes the environmental impacts of technology to students who enter in these programs with preconceived notions that sustainability is wholly about the environment.   Introducing social and economic issues and inequality is critical to producing a generation of engineers who understand sustainability much more broadly and are empowered through education and awareness to do something to improve sustainability practice throughout their careers.
